etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin, ablative of folium ‘leaf’, in medieval Latin used in references to mean ‘on leaf so-and-so’. The original sense of in folio (from Italian in foglio) was ‘in the form of a full-sized sheet or leaf folded once’ (designating the largest size of book)

definitions: an individual leaf of paper or parchment, numbered on the recto or front side only, occurring either loose as one of a series or forming part of a bound volume.
shortDefinitions: individual leaf of paper or parchment

definitions: the page number in a printed book.
a sheet of paper folded once to form two leaves (four pages) of a book.
shortDefinitions: sheet of paper folded once to form two leaves four pages of book

definitions: a size of book made up of folio sheets of paper
shortDefinitions: size of book made up of such sheets

definitions: a book or manuscript made up of folio sheets of paper; a volume of the largest standard size
shortDefinitions: book or manuscript made up of sheets of paper folded in such way
